meta.title: Writing a Proposal for Your Dissertation: Guidelines and Examples
meta.author: Steven R. Terrell

parts.title: Mastering the Dissertation Proposal
parts.body: Writing a dissertation proposal is tough, and it's the starting point of your doctoral journey—crucial for success but where many students stall. This book emphasizes proposal writing, which consists of defining a clear research problem, stating its purpose, asking relevant questions, and laying out a detailed plan for your study. You'll find support for finding and developing your problem statement, reviewing literature, and choosing between quantitative and qualitative research methods. A strong proposal is critical as half of students don't graduate because they can't clarify what they want to research. If you're struggling to start, it's likely because the "problem is the problem" – meaning students struggle to focus their research into a precise problem statement.

parts.title: Crafting a Strong Problem Statement
parts.body: This text discusses writing problem statements for research proposals. To formulate a good problem statement, it should have the following characteristics: it must be clear and concise, include all variables considered, and omit any researcher bias. For instance, a problem statement can focus on the high failure rate of algebra students at a specific institution, providing background and significance supported by literature, to justify its investigation. Attributes of a good problem statement include its relevance to the researcher, a manageable scope, the researcher's preparedness with knowledge and resources, the feasibility to collect and analyze data, practical or theoretical significance, and adherence to ethical standards. Following these criteria ensures the study's viability. Ultimately, a well-crafted problem statement acts as a cornerstone for your proposal, completed with structured purpose, research questions, and hypotheses for validation.

parts.title: Reflections on Mixed Methodologies and Adapting to Unsuccessful Research Outcomes
parts.body: This section illustrates a professor's research journey related to mixed methodologies and tackling a failed intervention study. In mixed methods research, both quantitative and qualitative approaches are merged to deeply understand a research question. For instance, quantitative data might imply one thing, but qualitative interviews can explain unexpected results. Here, it’s crucial to examine what happens when a research plan fails - it's part of research reality. A failed hypothesis doesn’t necessarily mean failure—it shows what doesn’t work and paves the way for future studies. The core lesson is designing a good study by strictly following a well-crafted proposal, regardless of outcome. When developing your research questions, integrate them with problem and purpose statements, ensuring coherence. Observing how a researcher adjusted their approach and learned from an unplanned outcome emphasizes adaptability in valid research design.

parts.title: Chapter 3 Proposal: Research Methodology Basics
parts.body: Chapter 3 of your proposal is crucial as it details the research method that drives your dissertation. There are different types of research methods, like quantitative, qualitative, or mixed methods, each with distinct philosophies and procedures. To choose the right method, understand research paradigms—the philosophical lens guiding your study. Components of these paradigms include axiology (beliefs about ethics), ontology (beliefs about reality), epistemology (researcher’s role), and methodology (approach to research questions). Scientists must define their paradigm as quantitative researchers aim for objectivity and qualitative researchers seek meaning through close participant interaction. An important step in Chapter 3 is identifying your study's population and establishing a sample using either random (probabilistic) or nonrandom (nonprobabilistic) methods. Quantitative methods usually employ random sampling for generalizability, ensuring that the sample represents the whole population accurately, thus avoiding sampling bias and sampling error. Techniques such as stratified, cluster, and systematic sampling help achieve this representativeness. A small demonstration using a hypothetical group illustrated how sampling errors could occur when selecting samples from a population, emphasizing the importance of strategic sampling techniques.

parts.title: Sampling Methods in Research
parts.body: When conducting research, it’s essential to understand the concepts of random and nonrandom sampling. 1. Simple Random Sampling gives everyone in the population an equal chance to be selected, reducing sampling bias. This is useful when polling voters, where demographics like political party should be reflected in the sample. 2. Careful caveats include ensuring a large sample size to reduce sampling error, and ensuring every population member has an equal chance of selection, crucial in probabilistic sampling. 3. Cluster Sampling involves selecting whole groups and is used when true random sampling isn’t feasible. This may introduce bias if groups vary greatly. The goal in sampling is to reflect the population while mitigating biases, critical for ethical and accurate research outcomes.

parts.title: Types of Quantitative Data
parts.body: We delve into different types of numeric data in quantitative research, which affects the study design and analysis. The four types are: nominal data, like gender or ethnicity, which are simple category counts; ordinal data, such as class rank, which involves ranking but not equal increments; interval data, like test scores, where intervals are equal but not necessarily an absolute scale; and ratio data, such as weight, where a true zero exists and we can compare ratios. Understanding these data types is crucial for researchers to choose the appropriate analysis.

parts.title: Research Design and Validity Control
parts.body: This section delves further into quantitative research designs, emphasizing their various forms and how each can control or fail to control threats to validity. It introduces experimental designs classified as pre-experimental, quasi-experimental, and true experimental designs. Each design varies in terms of control, with true experiments offering the highest level of reliability due to random assignment of subjects to groups. This allows hypotheses testing and definite conclusions about causal relationships. Pre-experimental designs are noted for their lower control and are often used to explore ideas. Pre-experimental designs are explained with examples such as the One-Shot Case Study and One-Group Pretest-Posttest Design, each demonstrating differences in group setup and measurement points. A static group comparison is highlighted as two groups are only measured after the treatment, lacking pretest data, thus not controlling for many validity threats. For more robust research, quasi-experimental designs like nonequivalent control group design offer improved internal validity by utilizing pre-existing groups with treatment assignments, mitigating some validity threats. Meanwhile, time-series designs analyze data over time, showing changes post-intervention.

parts.title: Qualitative Research Methods
parts.body: Chapter 6 delves into Qualitative Research Methods, which differ from Quantitative Methods by focusing on understanding the "who?", "what?", "when?", "where?", and "why?" questions. Unlike quantitative research that uses numbers to define events, qualitative research gathers text-based data to explore social life through Exploratory, Descriptive, and Explanatory research. There are six common methodologies: Narrative, Phenomenological, Ethnographic, Case Studies, Grounded Theory, and Content Analysis research, each providing unique insights into human experiences.

parts.title: Qualitative Data Analysis and Credibility
parts.body: Analyzing qualitative data involves finding patterns, concepts, and relationships to answer research questions. Unlike quantitative research, there is no standard method for analysis. Key aspects include reliability, focusing on data process dependability - such as consistent interview guidelines and procedure. It's essential to ensure interview transcriptions are accurate, often by checking recordings while reviewing transcripts. This familiarization with data is crucial before starting analysis. Qualitative analysis may begin alongside data collection, adjusting interviews and literature reviews as needed. Although no single "best way" exists, common approaches include narrative analysis—identifying themes in stories; phenomenological analysis—understanding experience essence; and ethnographic analysis—triangulating data from an insider's perspective. Grounded theory involves open coding, axial coding, and developing theories based on data. While these methodologies involve flexibility, credibility and trustworthiness remain central to a robust qualitative study.

parts.title: Participants and Research Procedures
parts.body: Participants for the research will be females living in NYC homeless shelters. A purposive sample of 12-15 will be identified for interviews after obtaining institutional approval. The interviews focus on circumstances leading to the shelter stay. Before this, the researcher will study homelessness literature in the US. Participants will sign a consent form assuring anonymity, volunteer participation, and no interference with their government services. The results are to develop a theory on homelessness among women.

parts.title: Summary of Presentation and Attrition Studies
parts.body: The first section outlined the plan for presenting results, which will be shared in Chapters 4 and 5 of a dissertation report and given to the tutoring service owners. The quantitative and qualitative data will help produce a report to assess the tutors' effectiveness. In the second section, we learned about a study regarding military academy attrition. It aims to create a screening tool to improve admissions by studying factors leading to students leaving the academy. Qualitative and quantitative data will be collected and analyzed to align identified factors.

parts.title: Research Methodologies Overview
parts.body: The text discusses different types of research methodologies, with a focus on qualitative, quantitative, and mixed methods approaches. For qualitative research, validity involves ensuring data collection is consistent. Triangulation and member checking are strategies used for maintaining validity. Mixed methods research involves combining qualitative and quantitative data to explore a research question more comprehensively. This approach often requires merging data sets and analyzing them together to provide insights. The design for mixed methods could be sequential-exploratory, where qualitative data is gathered first or concurrent, where data is collected simultaneously. Understanding both sampling methods and research design helps guide the study.
